29978(he0:13):Are theyΕΙΣΙ<WG1510.2.6><WTnull> notΟΥΧΙ<WG3780><WTprt-i> allΠΑΝΤΕΣ<WG3956><WTa-npm> ministeringΛΕΙΤΟΥΡΓΙΚΑ<WG3010><WTa-npn> windsΠΝΕΥΜΑΤΑ<WG4151><WTn-npn>,<RF>winds is seen as a transient, "passing" thing (eccl 1.17). that angels are transitory is derived from the context above. Pneuma being rendered "winds" follows the context of vs 7, which says that God makes his angels "winds" (and this be rendered winds because "winds" is in the context of "fire" in that verse). Angels have turned into "a flaming fire" in the instance with the burning bush (ex 3.2), and into winds in the instance of the four winds of heaven used as ministers of God's word (eze 37.9) as well as other places (1kg 19.12 LXX, job 4.12-20). What this means is that the angels will turn into different things for God's use, such as to minister for human Christians (he 1.14), or with the author's example to transport God down to earth (ps 104.2-4), or anything else God uses them for, and can not go further than being transitory "winds" because their whole purpose is to be short-lived tools for God. Also, the author may have spoken these with the view to persuade the audience from the worshipping of angels (cf. col 2.18).<Rf> being sentΑΠΟΣΤΕΛΛΟΜΕΝΑ<WG649><WTv-ppp-npn> intoΕΙΣ<WG1519><WTprep> serviceΔΙΑΚΟΝΙΑΝ<WG1248><WTn-asf> afterΔΙΑ<WG1223><WTprep> the onesΤΟΥΣ<WG3588><WTt-apm> intendingΜΕΛΛΟΝΤΑΣ<WG3195><WTv-pap-apm> to inheritΚΛΗΡΟΝΟΜΕΙΝ<WG2816><WTv-pan> salvationΣΩΤΗΡΙΑΝ<WG4991><WTn-asf>?<WG><WT>

29978(he0:13):Are theyΕΙΣΙ<WG1510.2.6><WTnull> notΟΥΧΙ<WG3780><WTprt-i> allΠΑΝΤΕΣ<WG3956><WTa-npm> ministeringΛΕΙΤΟΥΡΓΙΚΑ<WG3010><WTa-npn> windsΠΝΕΥΜΑΤΑ<WG4151><WTn-npn><RF> mustwinds is seen as a transient, "passing" thing (eccl 1.17). that angels are transitory is derived from the context above. Pneuma being rendered "winds" follows the context of vs 7, which says that God makes his angels "winds" (and this be rendered winds because "winds" is in the context of "fire" in that verse). Angels have turned into "a flaming fire" in the instance with the burning bush (ex 3.2), and into winds in the instance of the four winds of heaven used as ministers of God's word (eze 37.9) as well as other places (1kg 19.12 LXX, job 4.12-20). What this means is that the angels will turn into different things for God's use, such as to minister for human Christians (he 1.14), or with the author's example to transport God down to earth (ps 104.2-4), or anything else God uses them for, and can not go further than being transitory "winds" because their whole purpose is to be short-lived tools for God. Also, the author may have spoken these with the view to persuade the audience from the worshipping of angels (cf. col 2.18).<Rf>, being sentΑΠΟΣΤΕΛΛΟΜΕΝΑ<WG649><WTv-ppp-npn> intoΕΙΣ<WG1519><WTprep> serviceΔΙΑΚΟΝΙΑΝ<WG1248><WTn-asf> afterΔΙΑ<WG1223><WTprep> the onesΤΟΥΣ<WG3588><WTt-apm> impendingΜΕΛΛΟΝΤΑΣ<WG3195><WTv-pap-apm> to inheritΚΛΗΡΟΝΟΜΕΙΝ<WG2816><WTv-pan> salvationΣΩΤΗΡΙΑΝ<WG4991><WTn-asf>?

29968(he0:3):having becomeΓΕΝΟΜΕΝΟΣ<WG1096><WTv-2amp-nsm> so muchΤΟΣΟΥΤΩ<WG5118><WTd-dsm> better thanΚΡΕΙΤΤΩΝ<WG2908><WTa-nsm> theΤΩΝ<WG3588><WTt-gpm> angelsΑΓΓΕΛΩΝ<WG32><WTn-gpm>, he has inheritedΚΕΚΛΗΡΟΝΟΜΗΚΕΝ<WG2816><WTv-rai-3s> a nameΟΝΟΜΑ<WG3686><WTn-asn> as muchΟΣΩ<WG3745><WTk-dsn> more diverseΔΙΑΦΟΡΩΤΕΡΟΝ<WG1313><WTa-asn-c> beyondΠΑΡ<WG3844><WTprep> themΑΥΤΟΥΣ<WG1473><WTp-apm>.
29978(he0:13):Are theyΕΙΣΙ<WG1510.2.6><WTnull> notΟΥΧΙ<WG3780><WTprt-i> allΠΑΝΤΕΣ<WG3956><WTa-npm> ministeringΛΕΙΤΟΥΡΓΙΚΑ<WG3010><WTa-npn> windsΠΝΕΥΜΑΤΑ<WG4151><WTn-npn><RF> mustwinds is seen as a transient, "passing" thing (eccl 1.17). that angels are transitory is derived from the context above. Pneuma being rendered "winds" follows the context of vs 7, which says that God makes his angels "winds" (and this be rendered winds because "winds" is in the context of "fire" in that verse). Angels have turned into "a flaming fire" in the instance with the burning bush (ex 3.2), and into winds in the instance of the four winds of heaven used as ministers of God's word (eze 37.9) as well as other places (1kg 19.12 LXX, job 4.12-20). What this means is that the angels will turn into different things for God's use, such as to minister for human Christians (he 1.14), or with the author's example to transport God down to earth (ps 104.2-4), or anything else God uses them for, and can not go further than being transitory "winds" because their whole purpose is to be short-lived tools for God. Also, the author may have spoken these with the view to persuade the audience from the worshipping of angels (cf. col 2.18).<Rf>, being sentΑΠΟΣΤΕΛΛΟΜΕΝΑ<WG649><WTv-ppp-npn> intoΕΙΣ<WG1519><WTprep> serviceΔΙΑΚΟΝΙΑΝ<WG1248><WTn-asf> afterΔΙΑ<WG1223><WTprep> the onesΤΟΥΣ<WG3588><WTt-apm> impendingΜΕΛΛΟΝΤΑΣ<WG3195><WTv-pap-apm> to inheritΚΛΗΡΟΝΟΜΕΙΝ<WG2816><WTv-pan> salvationΣΩΤΗΡΙΑΝ<WG4991><WTn-asf>?

29947(phm0:7):Through whichΔΙΟ<WG1352><WTconj>--havingΕΧΩΝ<WG2192><WTv-pap-nsm> muchΠΟΛΛΗΝ<WG4183><WTa-asf> all-outspokennessΠΑΡΡΗΣΙΑΝ<WG3954><WTn-asf> inΕΝ<WG1722><WTprep> <FI>the<Fi> AnointedΧΡΙΣΤΩ<WG5547><WTn-dsm> to order uponΕΠΙΤΑΣΣΕΙΝ<WG2004><WTv-pan> youΣΟΙ<WG1473><WTp-2ds> theΤΟ<WG3588><WTt-asn> becoming thingΑΝΗΚΟΝ<WG433><WTv-pap-asn>--<RF>ie. because of the much benefits previously gained from the Philemons (vs 7), Paul has much confidence in them in Anointed (vs 20-21). Saying that ordering is in contrast to entreating here would contradict vs 21 which commends the Philemons' "obedience." That alternative reading saying that Paul wanted to "order as opposed to entreating" would not fit the context and would also be inserting an extra word "though" which is not in the Bible. Another rendering, which makes the text seem to imply that love is anti-commanding, is not even spoken about in the Bible and is based on unevidenced human supposition. Love himself commanded us to do things around the Bible (ge-rev), and his love does not change.<Rf>

25632(lk15:10):IfΕΙ<WG1487><WTcond> thenΟΥΝ<WG3767><WTconj> you becameΕΓΕΝΕΣΘΕ<WG1096><WTv-2ami-2p> notΟΥΚ<WG3756><WTprt-n> trustyΠΙΣΤΟΙ<WG4103><WTa-npf> inΕΝ<WG1722><WTprep> theΤΩ<WG3588><WTt-dsn> unjustΑΔΙΚΩ<WG94><WTa-dsn> mammonΜΑΜΩΝΑ<WG3126><WTaram>, whoΤΙΣ<WG5100><WTi-nsm> will believeΠΙΣΤΕΥΣΕΙ<WG4100><WTv-fai-3s> theΤΟ<WG3588><WTt-asn> unconcealed oneΑΛΗΘΙΝΟΝ<WG228><WTa-asn><RF>Greek for what we often stand-by as "true" means not concealing oneself; "unjust" here in its real greek meaning means not showing oneself ie. unjustly dishonest, which is characteristic of hiding ones or ones who work underhanded (compare jhn 3.20). The implication may be that there are two kinds of money, both personified in the parable: one does not conceal itself and therefore honest ("true" or "genuine"), and one that often does not show itself and therefore not honest ("pretend" or "not genuine"). <Rf> to youΥΜΙΝ<WG1473><WTp-2dp>?
